Company CO2 emissions fall by 0.5% in response to a 1 percentage point rise in the share of female managers.
This is the finding of a study by @ecb and @BIS_org staff on the relationship between gender diversity in the workplace and climate change https://t.co/gGEATWPVAt https://t.co/Qk2WoS0PSQ
https://t.co/iqLVndrO2r

Inflation has become broader and more persistent, says @Isabel_Schnabel at @bankofengland’s #bearconf2022. For inflation to stabilise at our 2% medium-term target, a gradual and data-dependent normalisation is needed that respects the communicated sequence https://t.co/sqmCmBah3T https://t.co/o0UAkH1b61
Working Paper: Monetary policy, macroprudential policy and financial stability https://t.co/AWSYUCR0Y5

Lane: If inflation rates are moving towards our 2% target in the medium term, which is now looking more likely – instead of being well below 2% as before the pandemic – we will adjust our monetary policy 

3/3

Lane: Geopolitical tensions are a very important risk factor right now, for Europe in particular

2/3

🧵While the data suggest that we could be moving closer to our 2% inflation target, there is great volatility and uncertainty, Chief Economist Philip R. Lane tells @FAZnet. We will comprehensively assess the economic outlook at our March meeting https://t.co/gojhNanmVm

1/3 https://t.co/GaEUw9IvrR

European banks face risks from global challenges like the pandemic, climate change and cybersecurity. Supervisory Board member Elizabeth McCaul met with civil society organisations to discuss how banks can manage such risks effectively https://t.co/ZEJrPEdd5D https://t.co/eFeJik0yCy

Elderson: We are strongly in favour of having more entities directly supervised by the new European Anti-Money Laundering Authority than is currently planned.

2/2

🧵Preventing the financial system being used for money laundering is important for the ECB, says Supervisory Board Vice-Chair Frank Elderson. Effective cooperation with the new EU Anti-Money Laundering Authority is therefore a priority for us https://t.co/Ha1OrvTxrW
 
1/2 https://t.co/5wgXDMCRcE
@PabloPerezA 😉

2day is 2sday 22.2.2022. 
So many 2s in one date is a rather rare event. Is there a better way 2 mark it than with euro coins?

Want to know more about €2 coins? https://t.co/Im0zXyLFjR https://t.co/IHkJrDliJm

Banks are maintaining solid capital and liquidity positions, as shown by the results of our latest annual Supervisory Review and Evaluation Process. Read more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/uvtCItPPrx https://t.co/SHypDU6mOJ
Results of the December 2021 survey on credit terms and conditions in euro-denominated securities financing and over-the-counter derivatives markets (SESFOD) https://t.co/WnllvKLhAB

We need a strong European anti-money laundering authority, says Supervisory Board member Édouard Fernandez-Bollo. Fighting money laundering is not our direct responsibility, but we stand ready to help however we can https://t.co/uVMfSjdxnK https://t.co/JMfK0KCW0C

Qualitative and quantitative data help us understand the banks we supervise. We have embarked on an ambitious digital transformation process that will help us make the best use of ever-increasing amounts of data.

Read more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/uvtCItPPrx https://t.co/fUpVCJzI3h

Suitable leaders are crucial for the proper functioning of a bank. If findings indicate that a leader may not to be suitable, the bank must reassess whether they should still be in the position.

Read about this and more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/uvtCItPPrx https://t.co/JTpE43QPcW

Panetta: Our digital euro project aims to ensure that everybody – including vulnerable population groups – continues to have access to safe public money in the digital era.
 
Full speech https://t.co/iRejkrKbKe
 
3/3

Panetta: Our goal is for people to be able to use a digital euro easily wherever they can pay digitally. It will need to add value for users, protect privacy and support competition and innovation, while safeguarding financial intermediation
 
2/3

🧵 To preserve the role of public money in a digital world the ECB is looking into issuing a digital euro for use alongside cash, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta.
 
Read the speech https://t.co/iRejkrKbKe
 
1/3 https://t.co/RUJGoRcDkV
Decisions taken by the Governing Council of the ECB (in addition to decisions setting interest rates) https://t.co/2DQ5VWImno

Banks’ exposures to the commercial and residential real estate sectors have become a key vulnerability. We are taking a close look at how banks are managing this credit risk. Read about this and more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/uvtCItPPrx https://t.co/UXtI5KVq8k

Banks need to intensify their efforts in measuring and managing climate and environmental risks, says Supervisory Board Vice-Chair Frank Elderson. The sooner they act, the smoother the transition will be for them, and for the economy they help support https://t.co/ZDAMlZUBCd https://t.co/SsrMtuS5MH

The euro area current account surplus grew to €310 billion, or 2.6% of GDP, in 2021, from €213 billion in 2020. The increase was driven by trade in services, which recorded its largest annual surplus since the introduction of the euro. Press release https://t.co/DJ4yTQKZkx https://t.co/PGjEuma14g
Euro area investment fund statistics (Q4 2021) https://t.co/PPySaQ7uN0

Lane: Inflation expectations show that current high inflation rates are not expected to persist but that the pre-pandemic below-target inflation pattern may not re-emerge. The anchoring of inflation expectations around 2% has also been reinforced by improving labour markets

3/3

Lane: Our monetary policy must take into account the near and medium-term forces that shape inflation dynamics. In line with our new strategy we will set our monetary policy to deliver our symmetric 2% target over the medium term

2/3

🧵If inflation stabilises around our 2% target in the medium term, this will allow for a gradual normalisation of monetary policy, says Chief Economist Philip R. Lane. We will tolerate neither under nor overreactions to emerging inflation risks https://t.co/MDGOxqj207

1/3 https://t.co/1SxJvotdiR

Register now and watch live at 15:00 CET today: Chief Economist Philip R. Lane talks about the forces shaping near- and medium-term inflation dynamics at an event on the eurozone economy and the ECB’s policies by @MNInews  https://t.co/OqZ4qLmtau https://t.co/Dyk0Usw3t8

Housing costs account for the single largest share of people’s spending and disposable income, according to two consumer surveys. The perception of housing costs also differs significantly by demographics across euro area countries https://t.co/BHRVAf6F4k #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/e1HMla0gjc

Housing costs can be measured using rent, house price and owner-occupied housing price indices. The latter can be an intermediate measurement of how housing prices and ownership-related expenses change over time 

3/3 https://t.co/ZYPoKeWOIv

The ECB’s preferred method for including owner-occupied housing costs in the price index is based on the prices that people pay when buying homes. We have published estimates of how including these costs would affect the inflation rates for most euro area countries

2/3

🧵Housing costs make up a large part of people’s spending. If these costs were included in how we measure inflation, what would be their impact? https://t.co/xJLxllsKwh #EconomicBulletin

1/3 https://t.co/BjfS3oqcGa

As it becomes more likely that inflation will stabilise around 2% over the medium term, we should start thinking about a gradual normalisation of our policies, @Isabel_Schnabel tells @FT. We must find the right balance between acting too early and too late https://t.co/tzJOBPKYWW https://t.co/82OdBzJpDE

#NextGenerationEU is a recovery plan that offers a unique opportunity to modernise our economies and make them more resilient. To realise its potential, it is key that Member States deliver on their national investment and reform plans https://t.co/FtltKbDrf6 #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/VwHUtqY6aW

Higher natural gas prices can hold back the euro area economy by reducing people’s disposable income and causing disruptions in supply chains. Recent gas price increases could reduce growth by around 0.2% in 2022

2/2

🧵Natural gas is the second most important primary energy resource in the euro area and the most important for the manufacturing sector. How will the current surge in oil and gas prices affect euro area growth? https://t.co/05iR0h37y9 #EconomicBulletin

1/2 https://t.co/KC7NycIzxM

President @Lagarde tells @europarl_en that inflation is likely to remain elevated for longer than previously expected, but to decline in the course of this year. The solid anchoring of long-term inflation expectations is reassuring, she says.

Full remarks https://t.co/LVSJ2A8lum

Lagarde: The euro made the lives of Europeans simpler and produced tangible economic benefits.

It has supported the free movement of people, goods and services and allowed citizens to work, study and travel in 19 different Member States without having to exchange currency.

Lagarde: The euro has become an integral part of our European identity, uniting us across borders, languages and cultures.

Sharing a currency is more than simply using the same means of payment; it is being part of a common endeavour.

#EUROat20
Coming up in 15 minutes: President @Lagarde attends the @Europarl_EN plenary session on the ECB Annual Report for 2020. Follow the webcast here https://t.co/NQCuw7Lupa https://t.co/2mhf8FF4C7

2022 marks 20 years of euro cash.

It only seemed appropriate for our Valentine's heart this year to go to our most precious symbol of European unity: euro banknotes and coins ♥️ https://t.co/H4QAUwOLw8
Working Paper: Market-stabilization QE https://t.co/KRVhGRAuMy

Although initially assumed to be short-lived, global supply shortages have been building up over time. Any long-term effects on potential economic growth in the euro area will depend on how long the disruptions last https://t.co/j5NnVq97rV #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/XGr5H6OQr0

Inflation is expected to fall below 2% in the euro area in 2023, according to the January Consensus forecasts. The inflation outlook in the United States is more uncertain though

3/3

Prices of products affected by supply bottlenecks and the economy reopening, such as cars and car components, play a crucial role in explaining inflation differences. The more advanced business cycle and higher wage pressure in the US economy are also key factors

2/3

🧵Energy prices were behind rapidly rising euro area and US inflation in 2021. Excluding energy and food prices, inflation in December reached 2.6% in the euro area and 5.5% in the United States https://t.co/myvWXLd5ox #EconomicBulletin

1/3 https://t.co/PioAyiQ5iw

Lagarde: The “greenflation” debate is exaggerated. The impact of the green transformation on the general price development is small, at least at the moment.
 
We must complete the green transition of the economy to prevent our planet from burning up.
https://t.co/7OIb05UvjT
 
3/3

Lagarde: We will carefully analyse how high energy prices are affecting other prices.
We will examine that closely in March and at each and every meeting over the coming months.
 
2/3

🧵 We must move gradually in adjusting our policy, President @Lagarde tells @RND_de.
 
If we act too hastily, the economic recovery could be much weaker and jobs would be at risk. Raising interest rates now will not lower energy prices. 
 
1/3 https://t.co/8pKoo77A38

We must complete the green transition of the economy to prevent our planet from burning up.

Lane: For these reasons, the initial price increases for those goods and services that experienced high demand and/or low supply can be expected to level off or even reverse

4/4

Lane: If disruption in supply is caused by a temporary loss of production capacity, for example a factory shutdown, a recovery in supply capacity will put downward pressure on prices once the shock has reversed

2/4

🧵Looking at inflation dynamics, the relative price dislocations caused by bottlenecks are intrinsically short-term, Chief Economist Philip R. Lane writes in #TheECBBlog. Price increases for scarce items stimulate supply, while cooling demand https://t.co/AoK7OWynua

1/4 https://t.co/EtkW46nKUQ

Inflation is likely to remain elevated for longer than previously expected, but to decline in the course of this year, says Vice-President Luis de Guindos. That is the most likely situation, but there are upside risks to this outlook https://t.co/LLBJlxwZsc https://t.co/BewYfyqC1N

Applications are open for our Graduate Programme!
Koen holds two master’s degrees, in law and economics. He applied to the programme for the opportunity to discover new topics and to work with people from different backgrounds.

Since the start of the pandemic, the outstanding amount of debt securities issued by euro area residents increased by 13.4%. This amount grew by an average annual rate of 5.2% in the last two years, compared to 2.1% in 2019. Read our press release https://t.co/5s0jH1gWDu https://t.co/CsH6yOpgFn

When the pandemic started, ECB Banking Supervision allowed banks temporary flexibility that gave them capital space to support their lending to people and businesses. We confirm these measures will expire according to our previously announced timeline https://t.co/JDgWdNFZqq

Elderson: Climate change is one of our key priorities for the coming years. There is good news, banks are forthcoming, and bad news, banks do not comply with our expectations. This year will be the year that the rubber hits the road. We expect banks to take real actions.

@FrankElderson: Climate change is one of our key priorities for the coming years. There is good news, banks are forthcoming, and bad news, banks do not comply with our expectations. This year will be the year that the rubber hits the road. We expect banks to take real actions.

Enria: It's not up to us which business lines banks should focus on. They should understand where their strengths are and focus their business on income-generating areas. We are supervisors – we cannot drive their cars. It is up to them to decide.

Enria: Loan moratoria have been removed in most member states. Our assessment is that only 0.3% of loans of significant banks are now benefiting from moratoria, which is very low. We ask banks to look through moratoria and assess counterparties unrelated to relief measures.

Enria: Shortcomings in internal governance may blur lines of responsibility, hinder effective risk management and weaken internal checks and balances. Banks also often have insufficient policies to promote diversity across the organisation, starting with the management body.
Enria: Banks must tackle structural business model and governance shortcomings. Since the financial and sovereign debt crises, most European banks have not been able to earn their cost of equity.
Enria: We will continue to focus on credit risk controls. While credit quality looks good on the whole, certain parts of the balance sheet may still deteriorate. These deserve close attention.

Enria: Banks’ capital and liquidity ratios are higher now than they were when the first pandemic-related restrictions were put in place. Only a handful of the banks we supervise are operating below the required and recommended capital levels.
Enria: Banks we supervise are resilient overall. Still, banks must have ample capital and liquidity to protect themselves if firms or households have difficulties servicing their loans.
Introductory statement by Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria at the ECB Banking Supervision press conference https://t.co/5Z5juXTs7U https://t.co/GZMMCYOb6U

Join Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria and Vice-Chair @FrankElderson as they present the 2021 Supervisory Review and Evaluation Process (SREP) results and take questions from journalists https://t.co/8ufLlMabmg https://t.co/DY6JTxJInZ

➡ Banks need to strengthen their risk control and governance frameworks to deal with possible knock-on effects from the pandemic on their balance sheet. Most of them also need to work on their business models as they are failing to generate returns above the cost of capital

3/3
